My daughter name is Aziza
I was listening  to Edd Sheeran  at Newcastle when he had no public following before he had his big break. it was next to the town moor. I was the only person who listened to him. I said to Edd you have what it takes. there was a parked lorry beside Edd only he himself was singing. I gave him a rapture. Edd if you read this I saw you on the Jonathan Ross show I did write to you via itv television. I had no response. best of luck with the new song. I do recall what you said to Jonathan ross " if it had not been for that man I would have given up. but I did not thanks.

0:07 "Azizam" (Ø¹Ø²ÛŒØ²Ù…) is a Persian (Farsi) word that translates to "my dear", "darling", or "beloved" in English. It's often used as a term of affection between close loved onesâ€”like couples, family members, or dear friends.
"Azizam" (Ø¹Ø²ÛŒØ²Ù…) is a Persian (Farsi) word that translates to "my dear", "darling", or "beloved" in English. It's often used as a term of affection between close loved onesâ€”like couples, family members, or dear friends.

More more more love
It's hard for a French person not to make the connection between Ed Sheeran's song "Azizam," which bears some resemblance to the magnificent song "L'Aziza" by French singer Daniel Balavoine, which was released in 1985. Both songs talk about the Oriental world and love. Was Ed Sheeran aware of the existence of this French song? The coincidence is disturbing, unless it's just a coincidence.

Subject: Concerns about Renaming the Persian Gulf  Dear President Trump,  I am writing to express my deep concerns about the recent efforts to rename the Persian Gulf to the Arabian Gulf. As a history enthusiast and a supporter of your administration, I believe it is essential to respect the historical and cultural significance of the Persian Gulf's name.  The Persian Gulf has been known by this name for centuries, dating back to ancient times. It is a name that reflects the rich history and civilization of the region, including the contributions of the Persian Empire. Renaming it would be a direct attack on the historian and ancient civilization of the region.  Furthermore, this move would be perceived as a stab in the heart for the Iranian people, who take great pride in their cultural heritage. Many Iranians have supported your administration's efforts to engage with their country, and this move would likely be seen as a betrayal.  I urge you to consider the cultural and historical implications of renaming the Persian Gulf. I believe that respecting the region's history and cultural identity would be a more constructive approach.  Thank you for your time, and I look forward to hearing your thoughts on this matter.  Sincerely,

Dear Ed Sheeran,  I just wanted to express my heartfelt gratitude for incorporating the Persian language in your beautiful song Azizam. As a Persian speaker, it means a lot to hear our language reflected in such a touching and artistic way on the global stage.  Your music has always connected with people from all walks of life, and this gesture of inclusion is deeply appreciated. Thank you for embracing cultural diversity and for shining a light on the beauty of the Persian language.  With warm regards and sincere appreciation, A grateful fan

The word Azizam is an Uzbek word
Azizam when a man refers to a woman, Azizim when a woman refers to her man. It is the Uzbek way of calling you beloved one. Of course, we take both words from the glorious Persian language.

Aziz (Arabic: Ø¹Ø²ÙŠØ²â€, romanized: Ê¿AzÄ«z; Hebrew: ×¢Ö¸×–Ö´×–â€, romanized: Ê¿AzÄ«z; Akkadian: ğ’€€ğ’£ğ’ª, romanized: Ê¿EzÄ«zÅ«) is a Semitic name from the root dva-zayin. In the Hebrew Bible, the root dva-zayin (×–-×–â€) means "respected, powerful, exalted". In 1 Chronicles, Aziz was the son of Shema and the father of Bela. Aziz (romanized), is attested as an Arabian king who ruled the Sampsigeramids of the Roman Empire. In ancient Levantine mythology, Azizos is the god of the morning star, of Aramaic and Arabic origin from Palmyra.  The Arabic goddess Al-Uzza, associated with the planet Venus, is named from the same root. Al-Aziz is one of the names of Allah in Islam. Ê¿Aziz without al- is used as a royal title borne by high nobles of Ancient Egypt. It is used in extant Semitic languages â€‹â€‹(Arabic, Hebrew, Neo-Aramaic, Mandaic, Maltese) and has also spread to non-Semitic language families such as the Berber languages, Caucasian languages, Iranian languages, and Turkic languages. Aziz is a common male given name, especially in the Muslim world, but it also continues to be used by non-Muslim peoples in the Middle East, such as the Jews, Assyrians, Armenians, etc. Iranians also started using this word after the Arabs.

Dear Ed Sheeran I am an Iranian and since your first song, thanks to the power of your words and your existential energy, I have felt more and more good about life every moment. Today, when I heard your beloved song, I could not stop my tears from flowing. I wish you and each of your loved ones health, happiness and endless blessings from my Lord Jesus Christ. Because I love you, I bow my head to express my respect and gratitude to you as a sign of courtesy, loyalty and respect that are the hallmarks of the life of genuine Iranians. I hope that one day no child on earth will see war or grow up without a family. Peace be upon humanity.

Azizam ğŸ’—ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡·
The main word in the song, Azizam, is an Arabic word meaning "my dear" or "beloved." Additionally, the Persian language is a dialect rooted in Arabic; they venerate Arab figures like Ali, Hussein, and Fatima. Their script is Arabic, and the architecture in cities like Isfahan and Shiraz reflects the Arab artistic style from the Abbasid era. Everything in the land of Khorasan is a legacy of the great Arab Islamic civilization.

In Uzbek, adding the letter "m" means that you own that thing or its yours. Aziza means dear, bloved and Azizam means my beloved, my dear. People usually put Aziza as a name, probably its already popular.

The kind of dreams where you wake up and can't stop smiling 56. The smell before and after it rains 57. The sound of rain against a rooftop. 58. The feeling you get when you're dancing. 59. The person (or people) that mean the most to you. Stay alive for them. 60. Trying out new recipes. 61. The feeling you get when your favorite song comes on the radio. 62. The rush you get when you step onto a stage. 63. You have to share your voice and talents and knowledge with the world because they are so valuable. 64.Breakfast in bed. 65. Listening to this nonstop
Azizam means "sweetheart". It can be used in many contexts. You can call the love of your heart Azizam. You can also use it for your children when you are speaking to them. It can also be used when you see an adorable little kitty or puppy. It's extremely versatile and one of the sweetest words in human lexicon ever. "Ed, Azizam, this is a beautiful song" (in English adjective comes before the noun, in Persian, it comes after). Btw, Ed's pronunciation is PERFECT.

azizam is a persian word  but it is a form of endearment used in all of central Asia (Afghanistan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan etc.) it is equivalent to the word habibi. this song unites many cultures and people together just through this word. much love to my central asian friends

I always liked Ed Sheeran, especially from his music, Perfect. I think that compared to other American singers, he made meaningful and meaningful music about love, which was the lyrics. Not like some singers who make a song with a piece of text and repeat it several times and make it trendy, I am very happy that Ed Sheeran made and sang this song in collaboration with Ilya. Because Ed Sheeran can sing live very beautifully, he is a down-to-earth and humane guy, and also his level of literacy and knowledge of music is high. The fact that he wants to get acquainted with Iranian musical instruments, works and learns, shows his understanding and level of knowledge, that he wants to understand other musical instruments and gain experience in them, that is, he did not just make hit music, but researched and experimented in it.

"Azizam" is a word of Persian origin, derived from the word "aziz" which means dear, beloved, precious. In Uzbek, "azizam" means something like "my dear", "my beloved", or "my sweetheart". The suffix "-am" indicates possession â€” so it literally means "my dear".  Where does it come from? It originally comes from the Persian language.  The word "aziz" in Persian means dear, valuable, or close.  It has entered Turkic languages like Uzbek and is now widely used, especially to express affection or closeness.  Itâ€™s often used in a sweet, affectionate tone, for example:  â€“ Azizam, how are you doing? â€“ Well, my dear, whatâ€™s new today?  Want to know more about its usage or how to use it in English conversations? ğŸ˜Š

Itâ€™s wild how people get territorial over words they didnâ€™t even invent.   Azizâ€™ meaning dear/noble in Arabic, with â€˜-amâ€™ being a Persian possessive suffix (â€˜my dearâ€™). Itâ€™s used in Persian, yes, but also in many cultures influenced by Arabic, like Turkish, Urdu, and Uzbek. Claiming itâ€™s exclusively Persian ignores history and shared cultural roots. Just a little info: The term â€œAzizamâ€ is not an Iranian word rather a Persian word. The Persian language is spoken in Iran, Afghanistan, Uzbekistan, Kurdistan and many more. The Persian language even exists in Hindi literature as well as in Turkic languages. You can find many Persian words existing in various languages across the world.   Afghanistan and Iran is where the Persian people came from and then migrated across many parts of the world.  Persian is a poetic love language, its beautifulâœ¨

Azizam Uzbekcha lug'atda ham bor
Azizam literally translates to "my dear" or "my beloved", it is commonly used in Uzbek as a term of endearment between loved ones, including romantic partners, close friends, and family members. You are welcome! :D Spread the good vibes!

Hey, Azizam is not only Persian. Its very common in turkic nations to call your beloved one Azizam. And it actually derives from Arabiz language, you can see that one of the Allah's 99 names is Al-Aziz. So, its not only a persian word.

Besides the word Azizam and the Persian tunes, the song conveys the philosophy of the great Persian polymath and sage Hakim Omar Khayyam who advocated cherishing the moment you are living as you don't know whether this is the last breath you are taking, or not.

Amazing
I need to mention that Ed Sheeran could have used the word "aziz," which is Arabic, but he chose to use "azizam," which is a Persian word. Since the languages are closely related, it doesn't mean that "azizam" is Arabic! The idea and intention of Ed Sheeran was to use a Persian word, and even in the music video, he goes into a store where "azizam" is written in Persian! Please don't confuse Arabic and Persian. They are similar, but they are not the same! Thank you.ğŸ™„â™¥ï¸

Sooooo funny.ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ wait! Why azizam?
Oh my GOD thank youuuuu
"Azizam" is one of those magic words in Persian. It is a deeply affectionate and versatile term carrying a wealth of positive emotions. It's much more than a simple word; it's a warm expression of connection and care. It is used for Endearment and Love: My dear, My Love, My beloved, Sweetheart, Darling, My precious, My sweet one, You are dear to me, I care about you. It is also used to express Respect and Fondness; It can be used towards elders, teachers, or people you want to show respect to;  it carries a tone of valuing the person; Used between close friends to express deep affection and appreciation. It's a common way to address someone you feel close to, regardless of the specific type of relationship (even a salesman can use it for customers). When someone is upset or in pain, saying "Azizam" can be a way to offer comfort and reassurance.   Using "Azizam" can make a request sound gentler or a statement less harsh. "Azizam" is a warm emotional blanket in Persian.
Thanks mate.

Azizam" (Ø¹Ø²ÛŒØ²Ù…) is a Persian term of endearment meaning "my dear" or "my beloved", and it's used with a wide range of people, from lovers to friends and family.  Here's a more detailed explanation: Origin: "Azizam" comes from the Persian word "Aziz" (Ø¹Ø²ÛŒØ²), which means "dear," "beloved," or "precious". The suffix "-am" (Ù€Ù…) is a possessive pronoun in Persian, meaning "my".  Usage: It's a common and versatile term of endearment, used in a variety of contexts.  Examples: You can use it with lovers, friends, family members, or even acquaintances.  You might hear Iranians use it when they see something cute or sweet, almost as an equivalent of "awww".  It can also be used as a general greeting or a way to show affection.

Love the songğŸ¥° One thing tho. "Aziz" is NOT a Persian word. It's Arabic. It was mixed with Farsi when Arabs attacked us 1400 years ago and tried to change the language.  One hint for Iranian to see if a word is Arabic or not is to see if the root matches known Arabic formats.   Ø¹Ø²ÛŒØ² Ù…ØµØ¯Ø± ÙØ¹ÛŒÙ„   The Persian version of the world can be "Eshgh"  So "Eshgham" means "my love. Also Azizam means "My dear" not "my Love"   Sorry for the information that no one asked for.

We Persiansâ€¦  we fell in love through words,  we spoke our hearts,  we found peace,  we turned longing into poetry.  Sometimes we didnâ€™t say much â€” just an â€œAzizamâ€â€¦ and that was enough. Now when these words cross borders â€”  when they echo in songs or show up in other languages â€”  thatâ€™s not just coincidence.  Thatâ€™s culture moving quietly through hearts.  Not with force, not with power â€” but with feeling.  With something real.  With something that still makes people stop... and feel something.

Ø¹Ø²ÛŒØ²Ù…â¤ Azizam (my dear)
Azizm stuck in my mindâ¤
Azizam literally translates to "my dear" or "my beloved", it is commonly used in Persian as a term of endearment between loved ones, including romantic partners, close friends, and family members. You are welcome! :D Spread the good vibes!

For those who didn't notice, this song was actually made in an Iranian, dancy rhythm style called "Shish-O-Hasht" (literally meaning 6'8 time signature), which really added to the Iranian flavour of this work.

*Azizam* literally translates to "my dear" or "my beloved", it is commonly used in Persian as a term of endearment between loved ones, including romantic partners, close friends, and family members. You are welcome! :D Spread the good vibes!

I am Uzbek and I know the meaning of this word because there are many words in Uzbek language that originated from Persian (Farsi). Also, in Uzbekistan we have names like Aziza and Aziz. I am so happy to hear from a singer like you, a name that is related to our culture, not only our culture but also our historically related nation.
Persian empire, Cyrus the great, first declaration of human right, all that thosands of years before Islam and after Islam everything the Muslim use to say Islam is good comes from perisans from poets like ferdosi, khayam, hafez, scientists, polymaths. Even the number system and algebra comes from a Persian called al-khorazmi. Today more than 80% of Iranians hate their government (the Islamic republic) because this government has been oppressing them for 46 years and trying to take away their identity as Persians and enforce Islam on them. For context Persians have resisted arabization for centuries they ultimately in order to stop the bloodshed of their people mostly converted to Islam but kept their Zoroastrian roots till this day. And because of the current regimes authoritarian ways they now are leaving Islam in millions. There was a study that shocked everyone as it showed only 5-10% of Iranians actually practice Islam. 60% have completely rejected it while 20% call themselves Muslims just because the believe in god but donâ€™t believe in any of the Islamic practices and profits. Iranians also want peace with Isreal and USA. They actually hope that their crown prince Pahlavi will return to iran and free them from the theocracy of Khomeini who was actually Indian decent! Many of the leaders in iran are not even Iranians they are Arabs who are occuping iran and have taken it hostage

Love it already ğŸ˜­ğŸ˜­
For those who do not know Iran was called Persia until they changed the name to Iran in 1939 because Iran is the word for Persia in Farsi. Like how Germany is Deutschland in German.   Hope everyone welcomes some Persian culture in their life today and learns the rich culture of Persians(Iranians). We aren't the enemy despite the actions of our despicable government.   We aren't another sect of Arabs, we are Persian and thank you Ed for making this beautiful song MAKING PERSIAN GREAT AGAIN
Thank you Ed! The term "AZIZAM" is derived from Farsi (Persian), meaning "My Love".   Farsi is my first language, and to hear a Persian word of endearment in a popular western culture song from a very popular western culture pop artist makes this moment noteworthy mostly due to our societies demonization of Persian culture and traditions (I will never get over how badly they made us look in the movie 300).   It also doesn't help that Iran's current government is corrupt.   As a Persian man staying true to my heritage and culture has always been my mission in life. I speak it fluently despite being born in the U.S and have spent so much time defending Persian culture against the tyranny of Iran's Islamic Republic.   I have also spent a lot of time teaching my American neighbors about Persian culture and traditions.   One time as a child my neighbors called the cops on us because we were jumping over fire in our backyard. They thought we were doing some sort of witchcraft and I remember my parents explaining to them what "Chaharshanbe Suri" where People gather around bonfires and jump over them, symbolizing cleansing and purification during the Persian New Year celebrations "Norooz". Teaching my fellow Americans about the hidden beauty behind ancient Persian Zoroastrianin traditions is my life mission.   While Islam has attempted to erase Persian cultural heritage, I remain grateful to the Persian dynasties that preserved their traditions despite the Muslim conquest of Persia (modern-day Iran).   Warmest wishes to fellow American-Persian (Iranian) individuals and to all global celebrants of Norooz, one of my most cherished holidays.   Thank you Ed Sheeran for this tribute to my childhood and culture.
